text: üé± Muni bonds on track for 7th monthly gain, with zero down days in Feb & just two YTD. Strong inflows & reinvestment drove returns, but Mar is munis' weakest month as reinvestment demand fades. Long-end munis still offer attractive tax-equivalent yields [RJ Up & Adam] https://t.co/8AQFlAGzJc

üáØüáµ Foreign investors pour ¬•1.78T ($11.5B) in Japanese stocks, largest weekly inflow in decade. Optimism centers on PM Takaichi's tax cuts, fiscal stimulus. Higher borrowing pressures yen & yields, but economic growth & tech exposure keep outlook bullish [RJ Up & Adam]

üèÜ Small caps crushing large caps by 6% YTD, widest margin since 2021, signaling investor confidence in economic pickup beyond Tech. But large caps still show strong earnings & dominate preferred sectors (Tech, Health Care, Industrials, Consumer Disc.) [RJ Up & Adam]

üîÑ Supreme Court blocked Trump's tariffs under IEEPA, but administration reinstated 15% across-the-board tariffs despite midterm concerns. Effective tariff rate now 11% vs 13% pre-ruling. Lower tariff costs could modestly boost GDP, earnings. Refunds TBD [RJ Up & Adam]

üî¨ Headline GDP disappoints (1.4% in 4Q25 vs 3% expected), but underlying picture is upbeat (consumers & private investment stayed solid). Govt spending offset gains due to shutdown distortions. Core PCE hit 3.0% YoY, signaling just one rate cut this year [RJ Up & Adam]

üõ¢Ô∏è Energy leads S&P500 YTD at +23%, best start in 25 yrs, driven by US-Iran tensions pushing oil to six-month highs. But oil futures signal 7% decline ahead. Expect WTI at $55-$60/bbl by year-end, making Energy's gains vulnerable to reversal [RJ Up & Adam] https://t.co/nZvWnktp28

üõü Public corporate bond spreads stay steady despite private credit turmoil: high yield & investment grade widened just 7 & 5 bps MTD but remain flat YTD. High yield heads for its 10th straight monthly gain. Public markets show no broader stress yet [RJ Up & Adam]

‚ÜîÔ∏è Trade deficit widened in 2025 to hit a record $1.24T, up 2%, but the story splits in two: 
-1H25 saw a 27% surge as firms front-ran tariffs
-2H25 fell 20% after stockpiling ended
If 2H trend hold, 2026 deficit could narrow to ~$1T, smallest since 2020 [RJ Up & Adam]

üí∞ Core PCE inflation hit 3% in Dec, highest since Mar'25, moving further from Fed's 2% target. Tariff driving a temp pickup in goods prices; services inflation stayed flat. Income growth outpaced spending, boosting saving rate to 3.6% [RJ Economics] https://t.co/zAp8pPmJIQ

üìä 4Q25 GDP first release (prone to revisions) grew just 1.4%, strong slowdown vs 4.4% in 3Q25, as government shutdown cut federal spending by 16.6%. Consumer spending & private investment stayed solid. Inflation mixed: headline PCE 2.9%, core 2.7% [RJ Economics] https://t.co/rzNSqYA0wT

üèòÔ∏è New home sales down 1.1% vs 2024. Builders cut median prices to compete with existing homes while facing higher tariffs & labor costs. Lower mortgage rates helped but not enough. Supreme Court tariff ruling may ease pressure if new tariffs don't follow [RJ Economics] https://t.co/eAcrrIYBio

‚öñÔ∏è Supreme Court struck down IEEPA tariffs, but Trump admin will reimpose sector-by-sector, creating more uncertainty. This further delays employment recovery, until tariff clarity, which was expected after Liberation Day shock slowed hiring [RJ Weekly Economics] https://t.co/qbsRydiLjM

üîÑ Rotation beneath the surface: While headline S&P500 YTD performance has been flat, there's been significant sector rotation beneath the surface. Worst performing 2025 sectors (energy, staples, materials) are the best performing thus far in 2026 [RJ Weekly Headings] https://t.co/nlFHjfXAAR

‚è∞ Trump's State of the Union focus:
-Geopolitics: Peace board, Iran & Venezuela
-Policy wins: OBBBA (tax cuts), tariffs
-Markets: Record high equities & high rates
-Midterm priorities: Affordability, Immigration
Betting markets: Dems flip the House
[RJ Weekly Headings]

üí∏ Strong data (industrial production, housing starts, durable goods) lifted dollar after recent weakness. Rate differentials still favor USD & sentiment remains bearish, supporting rebound as fundamentals reassert. Expect range-bound trading to continue [RJ Up & Adam] https://t.co/eeno0kkhhk

üõ¢Ô∏è Separate, Distinct Markets: WTI hit 6-month highs on US-Iran & Russia-Ukraine tensions despite no supply disruptions‚Äîclassic geopolitical risk premium. Expect this to fade to $55-$60/bbl. While Nat Gas dropped to 4-month lows, erasing Jan storm gains [RJ Up & Adam]

üèõÔ∏è While higher yields affected foreign Treasury holdings in Dec, vs Nov's record-high levels, foreign investors bought $1.6T in US stocks & bonds in 2025, up from $1.2T in 2024. Despite "Sell America" headlines, US asset foreign demand remains robust [RJ Up & Adam]

üìÖHistory Lesson: Feb 19 marked market peaks before COVID (2020) & tariff sell-offs (2025). S&P500 fell 34% & 19%. Investors who stayed put earned 14% & 13% annualized returns from those dates. 
Lesson: pullbacks hurt, but panic-selling hurts more [RJ Up & Adam]

üì¶ Core durable goods orders rose 0.6% in Dec, beating expectations for 6th straight month. Shipments hit fastest pace since Jul. Data center & electric grid equipment driving strength. Robust capital spending supports Industrials sector strength [RJ Up & Adam]

üè† Home prices rose 2.1% YoY in Jan, slowest pace since 2013. 16 of top 50 metros saw prices fall. Plateauing shelter costs support cooling inflation. For buyers: 30-year mortgage rates hit their lowest since Sep'22, though affordability remains tight [RJ Up & Adam] https://t.co/7d2tax9Wow
